attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
·       A physical inventory count was carried out on April 10 2025, to verify the accuracy of stock records by matching actual inventory quantities against the figures recorded in the SAP system. Additionally, the count served to assess the effectiveness of internal controls over inventory management.

·       The physical stock count revealed the following discrepancies:

Ø  Bread stock showed a surplus of 13.5 Loaves,

Ø  Packing material had  a surplus of +716 pieces,

Ø  White flour had a surplus of +1.96 kgs,

Ø  Brown flour had had  a surplus of +0.30kgs,

Ø  Wheat bran had had  a deficit of -5.00kgs,

Ø  Utto experienced a variance of -12.32kgs,

Ø  Other material items had minimal variances.

The table below illustrates the findings:

 Findings

·       We also observed major variances between system records and physical stock take for some polybags items. This was explained to have originated from inaccuracies during the previous stock.

·       It was also noted that damaged polybags are not consistently recorded at the end of each shift.

·       This lack of documentation undermines transparency and accountability in inventory management. The table  below shows specific items with major variances;

Implications:

·       The lack of consistent recording of damaged polybags creates opportunities for manipulation or concealment of stock losses, reducing transparency and accountability.

The recurrence of stock take discrepancies suggests potential weaknesses in inventory control procedures and monitoring at the branch level.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should implement more robust inventory controls to rectify the detected inconsistencies and promote greater stock accuracy

·       The responsibility for recording polybags damages should rest with the slicers to ensure accurate tracking and avoid manipulation of figures, potentially concealing actual polybag losses.

value:
·       The controls in place for maintaining bread stock and other raw materials were generally effective.

·       However, several discrepancies were identified, primarily from errors made during the previous stock take.

·       These issues were largely due to the interchange of different polybags varieties, which led to variances in recorded inventory levels.

To address this, we will implement proper labelling of polybags, particularly within the storage area, to ensure clear identification and prevent similar errors in the future

·       The main concern noted from the stocks were the polybags movement controls that we will tighten from the packing section at end of every shift.

·       Proper arrangement of Naivas polybags will be done since most variances come from interchange

Utto was due to new 800gms tins introduced in rotation.

·       In the prior Audit, dated 11th March 2025,the following variances were noted:

ü  Bread stock had a shortfall of -133.25 Pieces,

ü  Polybags had -132 pieces,

ü  White flour had +25.43 Kgs,

ü  Brown flour had + 1.28 Kgs,

ü  Wheat Bran had -5.274 Kgs,

ü  Yeast 125g had +0.54 Kgs,

ü  Crates had nil variance,

Utto +0.44 Litres.

attributes.title: Bread Weights
attributes.description:
·       A spot check on April 11, 2025, assessed the weight of packed bread before dispatch to ensure compliance with weight standards.

·       The findings revealed inconsistencies across different bread varieties, with cases of underweight, overweight and correctly weighted bread recorded.

Ø  Incidence of Underweight Bread: Several bread varieties, particularly the 800g BT, 600g BT, and 200g ML, recorded notable percentages of underweight samples.

Ø  Overweight Bread: Some varieties, such as the 1.5Kg BT and 400g SN, showed a considerable number of overweight units, indicating potential overuse of raw materials and cost inefficiencies.

Implications:

·       The presence of underweight bread in the market potentially subject the company to fines, penalties, or legal action from regulatory bodies.

·       Delivering underweight products can result in customer dissatisfaction, damaging the brand’s reputation and potentially leading to loss of market share.

Overweight bread could increase costs per unit, affecting profitability without necessarily increasing revenue.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The branch is recommended to maintain and regularly review existing weight control mechanisms during dough making and slicing to ensure consistent compliance with defined weight standards for all bread varieties.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To ensure consistent compliance with established bread weight standards, eliminate cases of underweight and overweight bread, and protect the company's brand reputation and profitability.

Identified Issues:

  • Cases of underweight bread loaves in several varieties (800g , 600g , 200g ML).

  • Cases of overweight bread loaves (1.5Kg BT, 400g SN).

  • Inconsistent weight control during production, attributed partly to overcooling and operational practices.

Remediation Actions:

 

Supervision and Evaluation:

  • Weekly reporting of bread weight check results to Operations Manager.

  • Monthly review of compliance percentages (Correct weight %, Overweight %, Underweight %) for each bread type.

  • Immediate investigation and corrective action if underweight incidences is rampant

  • Quarterly management review meetings to assess overall compliance trends and effectiveness of interventions.

value:
·       We will continue to uphold the existing controls to ensure proper weight regulation.

Additionally, we will closely monitor cases of underweight products and take steps to reduce their occurrence

·       Increased random spot checks of dough weights will be done.

·       High cases of overcooling was also noted

Corrective measures will be taken on cases of dough underweights.

·       In the prior audit dated 11th March 2025, it was noted that Underweights in packed breads were as follows;    

ü  400g CTW -23%,

ü  600g Bw-47%,

ü  800 CTW-3%,

ü  400g S/N-7%,

ü  200 g Minibread-36%,

attributes.title: Bread damages Percentage Analysis
attributes.description:
·       We reviewed the damages for the period from March 12, 2025, to April 10, 2025, to assess whether there were any instances of damages exceeding the established standard limits of 0.2% of total production for production-related damages and 0.5% of total sales for market-related damages.

·       Production damages accounted for 0.37% of total production, exceeding the standard limit by 0.17%, with a cost implication of Ksh 91,906.14

·       Market damages reached 0.33% of total sales, below the allowable limit of 0.5%

·       The findings were as detailed below:

Implications

·       Overage in production damages indicates inefficiencies in the production process, leading to avoidable wastage and cost escalation.

Rise in production damages could indirectly affect product quality consistency, which may, over time, impact customer satisfaction.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should implement a proactive preventive maintenance schedule for all critical production equipment, including the main mixer, to reduce the risk of unexpected breakdowns and production interruptions.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To reduce production damages to within the allowable 0.2% of total production, sustain market damages within 0.5% of total sales and minimize damages and associated costs.

Identified Issues:

  • Production damages exceeded the target, standing at 0.37% of total production (above the 0.2% Key Performance Indicator).

  • The excess damages were largely attributed to mixer breakdowns and use of the reliever mixer, resulting in lower dough quality.

  • Market damages were within the acceptable limit.

Remediation Actions:

value:
·       Due to a temporary malfunction of the main mixer, operations were shifted to the reliever mixer, which resulted in dough of slightly lower quality thus  majorly contributing to rise in production damages

The main mixer has since been repaired, and normal production has resumed

·        Proper follow up on production procedures to be strictly followed,

Mixer breakdown which took long to be attended also contributed to high damage levels.

·       During the prior audit dated 11th March 2025, it was found that;        

ü  Production bread damages were averaging at 0.32% of the production.

Market damages stood at 0.35% of the sales.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the mixing charts and summaries was conducted over a 30-day period, March 12, 2025, to April 10, 2025, to evaluate whether raw material usage aligned with the established BOM and if production standards were met. The goal of this review was to examine both shift-wise and summarized mixing chart documents, with a particular focus on the branch's Utto oil consumption, average yield and instances of remixes, as outlined below.

·       Below are summary of the findings:

ü  Utto consumption stood at 100%.

ü  Average yield was 192.78 loaves per bag.

ü  Average production was 119.57 bags per day representing 72.69% of the set target of 164.5 bags.

ü  There we no cases remixes for the reviewed period.

·       The table below shows a summarised findings of the mixing chart analysis.

Findings

·       Analysis revealed a slight misalignment between supply and demand.

·       Although production levels were relatively close to market needs, the average daily production of 177.97 bags fell short of the average daily sales demand of 183.53 bags, as shown in the analysis below:

Implications:

·       Un-attainment of production targets indicates that the production unit is operating below its optimal capacity, potentially leading to inefficiencies in resource utilization.

Strict application of balancing controls in response to lower sales volumes may hinder responsiveness to fluctuations in demand or potential market recovery as noted above leading to unmet customer needs, missed sales opportunities, or increased pressure on available bread stock.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should establish a more flexible production planning framework that aligns daily production volumes more closely with current and forecasted market demand.

Branch management should also strengthen coordination between sales and production teams to improve forecasting accuracy.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To align raw material usage, especially Utto oil and flour, with the Bill of Materials (BOM), ensure production targets are met, optimize resource utilization, and maintain high product quality and consistency.

Identified Issues:

  • Although Utto oil consumption and yield were generally within expected standards, average daily production (177.97 bags) fell short of the daily sales demand (183.53 bags).

  • There was a slight misalignment between supply and market demand.

  • No cases of remixes were recorded, which is positive.

Remediation Actions:

value: The target was not met largely as a result of strict implementation of balancing controls in response to reduced sales.
Our production plan is majorly against the demand to ensure only  fresh bread  is supplied to the customers.

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was conducted in the cash office to verify that the cash on hand matched the cash flow balance and to assess the effectiveness of the existing cash control measures.

·       All cash was properly accounted for, as outlined below:

Implications:

·       The proper accounting of all cash indicates that the existing cash control procedures are effective in minimizing the risk of misappropriation.

However, presence of a surplus amount needs to be investigated so to ensure nil or minimal variance between the both amounts.
attributes.recommendation: Continue enforcing strict cash handling policies and regular reconciliations to uphold accuracy and accountability.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To ensure strict control, accountability, and accuracy over cash handling processes, minimize variances and prevent potential misappropriation or errors.

Identified Issues:

  • Cash on hand generally matched the expected balances.

  • However, a minor surplus variance (+Ksh 22) was noted between physical cash and book balance, indicating potential counting, recording, or reconciliation errors.

Remediation Actions:

value: ·       Cash controls are effective, and we will continue to maintain them.
To maintain

·       In a previous audit, it was observed that all cash was fully accounted for.

It was also observed that at the time of the audit, Iou’s which were pending was amounting to Ksh. 12,800 which were not cleared within the 3 days as per the policy.

attributes.title: Mini shop
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was conducted at the mini shop on April 11, 2025, to assess whether operations were being carried out in line with the established standards.

·       The audit focused on reconciling stock movements with recorded sales and confirming whether Mpesa transactions aligned with the expected sales figures.

·       The Mpesa till records matched the expected sales, indicating proper reconciliation procedures were followed.

·       However, the variance noted can be attributed to transactional charges.

·       The table below illustrates the findings.

Implications:

The presence of payments from other routes in the mini shop Mpesa till could create confusion in financial records, making it difficult to track accurate revenue for each sales point.
attributes.recommendation:
·       The current controls in the mini shop are working effectively and should be sustained, with improvements implemented where necessary.

However, there is a need for proper documentation and approvals for any payments received from other routes to avoid potential misreporting or fund misallocation.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To strengthen financial reconciliation, improve accountability over mini shop transactions and maintain accuracy between sales records and Mpesa collections.

Identified Issues:

  • Mpesa till records generally matched expected sales figures, but minor variances were noted, primarily due to transactions from other routes being deposited into the mini shop till.

  • Potential confusion in financial reporting if payments from other sales points are not properly documented.

Remediation Actions:

value: ·       The controls at the minishop are functioning effectively and shall be maintained.
We will maintain the trend and work on where improvements need to be done

attributes.title: Debtors’ Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the debt balance as at 12 April 2025 was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.

·       The analysis focused on dormant unsecured accounts and clients who had balances and therefore were not supplied as detailed in below:

 

 

Implications:

·       If unsecured balances remain unpaid, they could negatively impact liquidity and operational efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: Sales representative is encouraged to actively follow up on overdue balances, particularly unsecured debts, to prevent them from becoming bad debts.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To strengthen debt management practices, minimize overdue and dormant debts and safeguard the company’s liquidity and financial health.

Identified Issues:

  • Several outstanding debtor balances were noted, some relating to dormant accounts.

  • Risk of unsecured balances turning into bad debts if not followed up aggressively.

Remediation Actions:

value: Sales team are following all outs standing debts.
Will engage the sales team on the balances

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       Production efficiency was assessed over a 30 day period, from March 12, 2025, to April 10, 2025 with the goal of determining whether the hired production workers were meeting the set efficiency target of 4.50 bags.

·       The actual production efficiency achieved was 4.38 bags per worker, falling slightly below the target.

·       The branch hired 33 additional workers beyond the required number, leading to an extra cost of Ksh 35,857.8.

·       A summary of the analysis is shown below;

Implications:

The inability to meet the efficiency target indicate that resources were not being utilized to their full potential.
attributes.recommendation: ·       Branch management should align staffing levels more closely with production forecasts and efficiency targets.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To optimize the utilization of production staff, achieve or exceed the target production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker and minimize unnecessary labor costs.

Identified Issues:

  • Actual production efficiency stood at 4.38 bags per worker, slightly below the target of 4.5 bags.

  • 33 extra workers were hired beyond the optimal requirement, leading to an additional cost of Ksh 35,857.80.

  • Reduced sales and shift cuts were cited as factors affecting efficiency.

Remediation Actions:

value: Due to low demand sometimes we have to cut shifts whereby u need to assign workers to complete the duty.

·       Machines breakdowns and slow response to the breakdowns contributed to low efficiencies also.

We will urge our team to improve on speed to cover up on the gap

·       In the prior audit;

Production efficiency was 4.36 Bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       The efficiency of human resource allocation in the packing area was evaluated by measuring packing efficiency over a 30-day period, from March 12, 2025, to April 10, 2025.

·       The assessment aimed to determine whether the company’s standard of 97 crates per slicer was being met.

·       The actual slicing efficiency recorded was 93 crates per slicer, which fell below the target of 97 crates per slicer.

·       22 additional packers were hired beyond the required number, resulting in an extra cost of Ksh 20,064.

·       The table below illustrates the findings;-

Implications:

·       With an actual slicing efficiency of 93 crates per slicer, the branch failed to meet the target of 97 crates per slicer, indicating potential inefficiencies in the packing process.

The hiring of more workers than required suggests inefficiencies in workforce planning and allocation, leading to avoidable operational costs.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Management should optimize human resource allocation in the packing area by aligning the number of hired packers with actual production needs to reduce excess labour costs.

Regular monitoring and evaluation of packing efficiency should be conducted to identify and address inefficiencies promptly.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To improve packing efficiency to meet the set target of 97 crates per slicer, optimize the number of packers hired and minimize unnecessary labor costs.

Identified Issues:

  • Actual packing efficiency recorded was 93 crates per slicer, below the target of 97.

  • 24 extra packers were hired, leading to an additional cost of Ksh 21,888.

  • Machine breakdowns and slow response to technical issues contributed to low efficiency.

  • Some packers were working at slower speeds, affecting overall productivity.

Remediation Actions:

value:
·       We plan to improve efficiency so we can meet our targets. Some packers are slow, which made us hire extra staff to prevent bread from overcooling.

Machine breakdowns also affected our efficiency, and KAF was slow to respond when support was needed.

·       Machines breakdowns and slow response to the breakdowns contributed to low efficiencies also.

We will urge our team to improve on speed to cover up on the gap
In the prior audit, the finding revealed that the average slicing efficiency was 91.73 crates per slicer.

attributes.title: Mileage Analysis
attributes.description:
·       The audit aimed to evaluate the fuel consumption of the branch's sales vehicles for the period from March 1 to March 31, 2025.

·       The primary objectives were to assess compliance with fuel efficiency standards, identify any inefficiencies and propose recommendations to optimize fuel usage and reduce associated costs.

Findings revealed that fuel consumption at the branch generally adhered to the set standards detailed below
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should maintain the controls in place and improve further where necessary.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To optimize fuel consumption across all sales vehicles, ensure adherence to standard fuel efficiency rates and minimize operational costs through improved monitoring and controls.

Identified Issues:

  • Generally, fuel consumption adhered to standard rates across most routes.

  • Minor fuel variations (both savings and slight overruns) were noted for some routes (e.g., Malakisi, Kamukuywa, Reliever routes).

  • Occasional vehicle overconsumption or underperformance was observed, although within manageable margins.

Remediation Actions:

value: We will continue to uphold controls in regards to fuel utilization per vehicle.
We will maintain
In the prior audit, it was noted all routes were compliant with standard consumption except for Vehicle supplying route Mateka - KCH 908B which over consumed two litres

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
·       We conducted an analysis of the generator’s fuel consumption rate as at 11 April 2025 and also for the period ended 31 March 2025 to determine if the Consumption rate was within the set standards.

·       We noted that the Fuel consumption rate for unit one the period 1 April to 12 April 2025 was 44.62 Litres/Hour as per tracker system as detailed below while at the book records consumption rate stood at 52.72 Litres/Hour.

·       For the month of March 2025, the consumption rate stood at 52.09 Litres/Hour as per the tracker while book records showed a consumption rate of 52.73 Litres/Hour

Implications:

The fuel consumption records had minimal variances although calibration is necessary for reconciliation purposes.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should uphold the existing controls and ensure proper calibration is conducted to facilitate accurate reconciliation between the two records.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To ensure accurate tracking, proper calibration and optimal fuel efficiency of the generator while maintaining full operational reliability during power outages.

Identified Issues:

  • Minor variances were noted between fuel consumption recorded manually (book) and through the tracker system.

  • The tracker showed a slightly lower consumption rate compared to manual records.

  • Overall, generator fuel consumption was within acceptable limits, but calibration adjustments were recommended for reconciliation purposes.

Remediation Actions:

value: ·       The generator's consumption was within the set standards.
To maintain
In the prior audit, the findings revealed that the consumption rate stood for unit one generator was at 54.64 litres per hour.
